1a: ^Hail, branded. I have been beseeched by the glorious Csalan, steed to the Director, to serve as his translator while he parlays with you.

s: ^I will hear his words.
^Parlay? With a horse? You must be joking.
^The revolution won't be delayed. Not by you, or your horse. Attack! <Combat>

c-0: ^*The horse speaks aloud in the horsetongue.* <Excellent. I had doubts you would be so agreeable.>
c-1: ^*The horse snorts, then speaks aloud in the horsetongue.* <I am not one to joke. This regards a matter most dire.>
^Csalan says he is not joking. He needs to speak to you, earnestly.

s: ^You don't need to translate my words back to him?
^What did he want to discuss?

c-0: ^Horses can understand our language, but Beast did not see fit to allow their throats to speak it. He does not need me to translate what you say.
c-1: ^<I am aware of the progress you've made through the camp. That you should penetrate this far into the Manse... does not bode well for our prospects of victory.>
^Csalan says that the victories you have won thus far against the guards are known to him. He sees you as a powerful and worthy opponent.

s: ^You don't need to translate my words back to him?
^What did he want to discuss?

c-0: ^Horses can understand our language, but Beast did not see fit to allow their throats to speak it. He does not need me to translate what you say.
c-1: ^<I am aware of the progress you've made through the camp. That you should penetrate this far into the Manse... does not bode well for our prospects of victory.>
^Csalan says that the victories you have won thus far against the guards are known to him. He sees you as a powerful and worthy opponent.

1c: ^<Every horse has heard the stories of the fates of those steeds that fall in battle against the Craft Folk. I wish to gauge your character, and determine what shall befall my form if you were to defeat me here.>

^The horses of the Confederation know that it is common for Craft Folk to feast on the flesh of the horses they slay in battle. Csalan wishes to learn if such a fate awaits him and the horses under his charge.

s: ^Why does this worry him?
^I have made my decision
^If my decision makes no difference, then what is the point in making it? <Combat>

c-0: ^<It is not dignified for a horse to allow themselves to be eaten like chattle.>
^Csalan says the indignity of it concerns them. He does not wish such a fate for himself or his subordinates.

s: ^Perhaps we don't need to fight at all. We will gladly accept your surrender.
^Why does this worry him?
^I have made my decision

c-0: ^*If horses can scoff, then this one did.* <We are resolved to fight to the death, no matter your answer.>
^Csalan says no horse would allow themselves to be captured. The horses will fight you, whatever your decision is.
c-1: ^<It is not dignified for a horse to allow themselves to be eaten like chattle.>
^Csalan says the indignity of it concerns them. He does not wish such a fate for himself or his subordinates.

s: ^You have misjudged us: that will not happen. I will see to it.
^I have no intention of allowing a being I have spoken with be eaten.
^I won't partake, but my fellows are starving. I will not order them to go without the meat your bodies would provide.
^And let a delicacy like him go to waste? I won't let that happen.
^I will do what I like, and you'll be too dead to stop me. <Combat>

c-0: ^<I would hear you swear this to me. Swear on whatever you hold most dear that you will burn our bodies to ash rather than eat from them.>
^Csalan wants to hear an oath from you declaring you will allow fire to consume their bodies rather than consume them yourselves. Swear it, lest whatever you hold most dear be forfeit to the Gods.
c-1: ^<I would hear you swear this to me. Swear on whatever you hold most dear that you will burn our bodies to ash rather than eat from them.>
^Csalan wants to hear an oath from you declaring you will allow fire to consume their bodies rather than consume them yourselves. Swear it, lest whatever you hold most dear be forfeit to the Gods.
c-2: ^<You disgust me branded. Never have I been more sure that our cause is righteous.>
^Csalan says that you disgust him, and your words only serve to prove him superior to you.
c-3: ^<You disgust me branded. Never have I been more sure that our cause is righteous.>
^Csalan says that you disgust him, and your words only serve to prove him superior to you.

s: ^I swear it before the Gods, lest...
^I owe you no oaths. Let us get this over with. <Combat>

1f: ^*The horse listens intently to your oath.*

s: ^... my life be forfeit.
^... I suffer for the rest of my days.
^... my name be forever stained.
^... my family dissolve our bonds of kinship.
^... I never return to the land I call home.
^... I never know wealth.
^... my sanity wither from the shame.

1g: ^*Csalan bows his head low, bending his front legs to add to it's depth.* <I thank you, branded. Now, battle can be postponed no longer. Show me the strength that has felled so many of my guards.>
^The great Csalan thanks you. He now invites you to battle. He wishes to test the strength that you wield.

s: ^I am curious to fight him as well. We are ready. <Combat>
^Finally! Let it be done! <Combat>
^*Grin wickedly.* Good thing I had my fingers crossed. <Combat>
